What is Pay on Delivery?
Pay on Delivery (POD) includes Cash on Delivery (COD) as well as Debit card / Credit card / Net banking payments at your doorstep.
EMI starts at 428 per month. EMI starts at 428. No Cost EMI available if you checkout only with this item. Options
EMI (Easy Installments)
  • Pay for your order in equal monthly installments (EMI), using any one of the cards in the table below.
  • Your bank will convert the payment into EMI in 3-4 working days.
  • To make this a No Cost EMI offer, the interest amount will be discounted from the price of your order. Your card will be charged for the item price minus the discounted interest. The total amount you will pay to the bank (excluding GST) will be equal to the price of the item. The bank will charge GST on the interest amount.

ba_doh
3.0 out of 5 starsGold colour has a gaudy look due to the white border. Looks very cheap !!
23 June 2018
Colour: Gold|Size: 32 GB|Verified Purchase
I have used the Redmi Note 3 for almost 2 years and am a strong supporter of the Redmi Line. The note 3 was giving minor issues with the buttons, therefore decided to replace. Between the "Redmi 5" and the "Redmi Note 5" - it was clear that the Note line is better. However, we were getting a very good exchange price for the Redmi 5 and ended up buying that. Rose Gold Redmi 5 in exchange for Rose Gold Redmi Note 3.

1. The Redmi 5 front frame (the border that gets seen behind the glass) is white. This makes the phone look awfully cheap. I do not understand how someone could select such a colour. While the note series looked premium, this one difference took all the premium out of the Redmi 5. I strongly discourage anyone from buying the Redmi 5 of Rose-Gold colour. Your cheap phone will actually look cheap. One star reduced for this.

2. Redmi 5 is thinner than the Redmi Note 3 and has a different "feel" to the touch. Redmi Note 3 had made a better tactile impression on us.

3. Functionally, everything felt the same. I am not comparing the technical specs as there are many websites that do this. The bottomline is that we ended up with a phone that worked almost like the old one (slightly faster) - but looked cheap and unpremium. The two stars reduced are solely for the cheap look of the white-bordered gold-coloured Redmi 5.

We found a workaround to the cheapness. If you, like us, have ended up purchasing this piece.
a) Buy a tempered glass made for the Redmi 5 black (the tempered glass should have a black border). This black colour will hide the gaudy white looks effectively. (We purchased ASIN: B07CJTNSKL, which is a perfect fit and quite good quality)
b) Buy a premium back cover - preferably one that will cover the edges effectively. With the tempered glass and the good back c-ver, the looks of the phone improves drastically and the money spent is justified.

We exchanged the Redmi 5 at around Rs 5K and the cover + tempered glass cost less than 700 ... so it ended well.

18 June 2018
Colour: Black|Size: 16 GB|Verified Purchase
I like phone for its cost but after switching from stock Android to miui feel that I've lost decent amount of storage due to bloatware. Having 16gb variant I'm not left with as much space as I had in my stock Moto device; after putting my songs and necessary apps, in left only with 4gb space.
Then there are further issues with miui. It keeps forcing me to use its bloatware despite I having made others apps as the primary apps. The phone's really thin and feels good in hand although quite large for my hands. But I guess there are hardly any newphones out there with display smaller than this.
I'd have bought a Nokia device for camera and stock Android but alas Nokia is costly for the amount users pay and this was a more value for money deal.
One thing that I again miss after buying this phone is colour choice. I've always bought white gadgets as they look really nice and premium. But xiaomi doesn't have a white colour. With gold appearing so stupid (i mean wasn't gold a colour for jewellery worn primarily by women? Why suddenly a gold colour is being pushed to consumers. I hate gold because it reminds me jewellery more than gadgets) and blue always being out of stock, I was forced to buy black.
